SubTopics: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
Content: Which ùóßùó™ùó¢ statements can be represented by the expression 4 √ó 8?

A.Choice: A teacher puts 8 chairs at each of 4 tables.

B.Choice: Tom buys 4 red markers and 8 black markers.

C.Choice: Marie shares her 8 marbles equally among 4 friends.

D.Choice: There are 4 rows of flowers. There are 8 flowers in each row.

E.Choice: There are 8 ducks in the pond. Then, 4 more ducks join them.

SubTopics: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.
Content: Ana starts eating lunch at 12:15 p.m. She finishes eating lunch 40 minutes later.
Which clock shows the time that Ana finishes eating lunch?

SubTopics: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.
Nolan has 16 pennies in one jar and 94 pennies in another jar.
He uses some of the pennies to buy a pencil that costs 25 cents. What is the total number of pennies Nolan has left after he buys the pencil? Show your work.
Nolan saves some more pennies and now has 187 pennies all in none jar. He finds 10 more pennies in his pocket.
What is the total number of pennies Nolan has after he adds the 10 pennies from his pocket to the jar?
The table shows the number of pennies Nolan saved each week for four weeks.
problems/NJG3M/media/3a.jpg
What is the total number of pennies Nolan saved during the four weeks? Show your work.

SubTopics: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Content: Which number line shows the correct location of the number 5/3?

SubTopics: Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Cindy is finding the quotient for 27 √∑ 9. She says, ‚ÄúThe answer is 18 because addition is the opposite of division and 9 + 18 = 27.‚Äù
Identify the incorrect reasoning in Cindy's statement.
Show or explain how Cindy can correct her reasoning. Find the quotient when 27 is divided by 9.

SubTopics: With accuracy and efficiency, multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that, one knows) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Content: Select the ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò equations that are correct.

SubTopics: Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step ‚Äúhow many more‚Äù and ‚Äúhow many less‚Äù problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Mr. Conley delivers packages. The bar graph shows the total number of packages he delivered on five days last week.
problems/NJG3M/media/8a.jpg
What is the total number of packages Mr. Conley delivered on Monday and Tuesday?
How many ùó†ùó¢ùó•ùóò packages did Mr. Conley deliver on Monday and Tuesday than he did on Thursday and Friday?

SubTopics: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Sandy draws a shape. She divides it into parts. Each part is 1/8 the area of the shape. Which shape could be the one Sandy draws?

SubTopics: Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l). Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.
Content: Carla buys apples and peaches at the store. The mass of the apples is 724 grams. The mass of the peaches is 471 grams.
How much greater is the mass, in grams, of the apples than the mass of the peaches?

SubTopics: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

Solve two-step word problems, including problems involving money, using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Content: A model of a playground is shown.
problems/NJG3M/media/11a.jpg
Find the area, in square meters, of the playground. Explain your answer using an equation or equations.

SubTopics: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
Content: Which ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò statements can be represented by the expression 24 √∑ 4 ?

A.Choice: Jake makes 242 muffins. He gives away 4 muffins.

B.Choice: Collin has 24 toy trucks. He sorts them into groups of 4 trucks each.

C.Choice: Amira has 24 trading cards. She puts them into piles containing 4 cards each.

D.Choice: Rosemary puts 24 stickers in each book. She uses enough stickers to fill 4 books.

E.Choice: Steven fills a new bookshelf with 24 books. He puts the same number of books on each of the 4 shelves.

SubTopics: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10‚Äì90 (e.g., 9 √ó 80, 5 √ó 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

SubTopics: Solve two-step word problems, including problems involving money, using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Third-grade students took a total of 1,000 pictures for the yearbook during the school year.

:ibox:‚Ä¢ Ted took 72 pictures.

‚Ä¢ Mary took 48 pictures.
What is the total number of pictures taken by the rest of the third-grade students during the school year?
Ella took 8 more pictures than Ted took. How many more pictures did Ella take than Mary?

SubTopics: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Content: A tablet has a rectangular screen with a width of 7 inches and a length of 9 inches. Select the ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò ways to calculate the area of the screen, in square inches.

SubTopics: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Content: Gina's bedroom floor is in the shape of a rectangle. It is 10 feet long and 9 feet wide. What is the area of Gina's bedroom floor?

SubTopics: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Select the ùóßùó™ùó¢ shapes that have parts that are each 1/6 of the area of the whole shape.

SubTopics: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.
Content: Select the equation that is true when the number 8 is put into the box.

SubTopics: With accuracy and efficiency, add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: Answer the subtraction problem below.

SubTopics: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Understand a fraction as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction as the quantity formed by a parts of size.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
An artist plans to paint a wall in a room. The wall is divided into 6 equal parts so that each part can be painted a different color.
problems/NJG3M/media/20a.jpg
The artist goes to the store to buy brushes and small cans of paint. He pays a total of $94.

:ibox:‚Ä¢ He buys 8 brushes that cost $5 each.

‚Ä¢ The rest of the money is used for the 6 cans of paint. Each can of paint costs the same amount.
How much does each can of paint cost? Show your work or explain your answer.
The artist starts painting the wall. The parts of the wall that look white are not painted yet.
problems/NJG3M/media/20b.jpg
Which statements about the wall are correct?
Select the ùóßùó™ùó¢ correct statements.

A.Choice: Each painted part is 1/4 of the whole wall.

B.Choice: Each painted part is 1/6 of the whole wall.

C.Choice: Each painted part is 2/4 of the whole wall.of the whole wall.

D.Choice: The fraction of the wall not yet painted is 1/6.

E.Choice: The fraction of the wall not yet painted is 2/4.

F.Choice: The fraction of the wall not yet painted is 2/6.

SubTopics: Represent a fraction on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size and that its endpoint locates the number on the number line.

SubTopics: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions by reasoning about their size, (e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent with the support of a visual fraction model.
Content: Which ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò comparisons are true?

SubTopics: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: Which ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò shapes are quadrilaterals?

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions with the support of a visual fraction model.
Content: Select the ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò fractions that make this comparison true.

SubTopics: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Content: Lavina wants to place a fence around a rectangular play area for her rabbits. The paly area will be 7 feet long and 4 feet weide.
What is the total length of fence, in feet, Lavina needs to place around the paly area?
